questions.explanation: XOR (exclusive OR) outputs 1 when inputs are DIFFERENT (01 or 10), and 0 when they are the same (00 or 11). It detects difference.
NAND = NOT(AND). First perform AND, then invert the result. NAND outputs 0 only when all inputs are 1.

questions.prompt: According to De Morgan's theorem, (A·B)' equals:
questions.explanation: De Morgan's first theorem: NOT(A AND B) = NOT(A) OR NOT(B). Break the bar, change AND to OR, complement each variable.

options: They can implement any logic function
questions.correctAnswer: They can implement any logic function
questions.explanation: NAND (and NOR) are universal gates because any Boolean function can be built using only NAND gates. NOT, AND, OR can all be made from NANDs.

questions.prompt: To make a NOT gate from NAND gates, you need:
options: 1 NAND gate with inputs tied together
questions.correctAnswer: 1 NAND gate with inputs tied together
questions.explanation: If both inputs of a NAND are the same (A), output = NOT(A·A) = NOT(A). This creates an inverter from one NAND gate.
XNOR = NOT(XOR). It outputs 1 when inputs are EQUAL (both 0 or both 1). Also called equivalence gate.
NOR = NOT(OR). Since OR outputs 0 only when all inputs are 0, NOR outputs 1 only when all inputs are 0.

questions.prompt: How many NAND gates needed to make an AND gate?
questions.explanation: AND = NAND followed by NOT. Use 2 NAND gates: one for NAND(A,B), one with tied inputs to invert the result.
A XOR 0 = A. XOR with 0 passes the input unchanged. This is the identity property of XOR.
A XOR 1 = A' (NOT A). XOR with 1 inverts the input. This makes XOR useful as a controlled inverter.
De Morgan's second theorem: NOT(A OR B) = NOT(A) AND NOT(B). Break the bar, change OR to AND, complement each variable.
A XOR A = 0. XORing any value with itself always gives 0. This is the self-inverse property of XOR.
